name: Letter from Lipsius, Justus to Clusius, Carolus, 1587-01-03

Critical.text: I[ustus] Lipsius Car[olo] Clusio V[iro] S[alutem] D[icit]. Amanter me, Clusi, et litteris tuis provocas et muneribus quae utraque repperi rediens e Germanico itinere quod susceperam, Deo me non favente. Nam Bremam dumtaxat attigi, redire coactus equitum interventu et vicinia hiemis, nisi hibernare cum magno meo incommodo voluissem in barbaris et incultis locis. Westfalia, opinor, tibi nota est, quae tantum abit a reliqua Germania et mutat, quantum haec ab Italia aut Belgica nostra. Si pertendere potuissem quo tendebam, fortasse et te vidissem Francofurti et alios amicos. Sed nunc ecce me iterum in carcere Batavo, quem mihi tamen iucundiorem facit amor in me et benivolentia civium et iuventutis cui studia nostra laborant. Te deseruisse Viennam audio. Si ita est, animusne tibi veniendi ad haec loca? Rogo, non suadeo (ancipitia haec rerum video) et tamen si animus, possimus, credo, conficere tibi honestum in Academia locum. Dodonaeum obiisse scio te scire. Honoraria hic non negantur tui similibus viris. Comes Leicestriae in Angliam abiit, sed, ut aiunt, rediturus. Multi de toto statu hoc ambigunt nec scribo subtilius aut fusius temporum aspectu. Hortulum beneficio magistratus possideo iam in urbe; eum si tua liberalitate (vide os meum!) exornare potuero, nimium quantum tibi debebo. Atque utinam mihi tale aliquid imperes! Reperies profecto Lipsium non animo solum, sed usu et re tuum. Doct[orem] Camerarium medicum salutes velim et nostrum Modium, quem silere miror et paene indignor. Nos Politica quaedam e Tacito et aliis parabamus, si non franget impetum servile hoc aevum. Vale, Vir Cl[arissime]. Leidae, III Non[as] Ian[uarias] M.D.LXXXVII. Franc[iscus] Raphelengius scriptioni huic intervenit, qui te amice salutat, gratias agit, rescribet prima occasione. Velim te, mi Clusi, adiunctas curare tuto Marpurgum. [Address:] Cl[ariss]imo et eruditiss[im]o Viro, D[omino] Carolo Clusio, amico. Francofurtum. [Clusii manu:] 1587. Iusti Lipsii Leydae, III Non[as] Ian[uarias] ad meas V Cal[endas] Octobr[es]. Accepi Viennae, XII Cal[endas] Aug[ustas]. Respondi VIII Cal[endas] easdem.

locum: In February 1587 Lipsius had been granted a new term as rector of Leiden university, hence it would be rather easy to convince its Board to invite the famous Clusius.

Dodonaeum: Rembertus Dodonaeus (Dodoens; Mechelen, 29 June 1517 – Leiden, 10 March 1585) had been personal physician to the Emperors Maximilian II and Rudolph II, but was dismissed by the latter in 1580. By the end of 1582 he became professor of Botany in Leiden.

annotations.text: Hortulum: On 4 August 1586 the city of Leiden offered Lipsius the usufruct of the garden of St-Catherine’s, owned by the city, for as long ad he stayed in Leiden. Moreover, the city would reimburse all expenses to improve the garden if Lipsius wwould ever leave the city. It was presented as an acknowledgement of his extra-ordinary merits towards the Leiden and its university, but was, in fact an attempt to make him renounce his plans of leaving Leiden.

Modium: Franciscus Modius (de Maulde; Oudenburg, 1556 – Aire, 23 June 1597) Latin poet and philologist, tireless in his search for old manuscripts, which he collated, showing himself a critical lector, quite familiar with the Latin language and its literature. The result was published in his Novantiquae lectiones, tributae in Epistolis centum (Frankfurt: Johann Wechel, 1584). From 1585 to 1587 he worked as corrector with the printers Sigismund Feyerabend and Johann Wechel.
